==39167== Profiling result:

I'll review tomorrow, been very busy lately.
I prefer `ops`, since we only need a metric for evaluating the computation overhead

> * We can use gradient or differentiation to indicate the gradient.  Given that most API(tensorflow, pytorch), and relay's high level API use gradient. I suggest we use the name gradient.

Do you mean renaming `autodiff.{h,cc}` -> `gradient.{h,cc}`?

> * Namespace how about:  tvm.expr.gradient?

Wouldn't it make more sense to put it in `tvm.tensor.gradient` since it works on tensors, not only on expressions? Also placing a submodule `gradient` into `tvm.expr` (or `tvm.tensor`) would require creating a directory `tvm/expr/` and moving the contents of `tvm/expr.py` into `tvm/expr/__init__.py`
@tqchen @zhreshold This PR is updated and all comments are addressed.
Zero elimination PR #2634
counting ops, or more specifically, MOPS(number of multiplications) is usually a good proxy for perf
Yes, I do mean these functions. A more general test is to use these save_dict function and then call graphruntime.load_params to load them in.
@jroesch can you elaborate and give an example?
@merrymercy can you open an issue to track the first order AD tuple support?

> I'll review tomorrow, been very busy lately.

@jroesch no rush. I'll take another pass later this week to iron out those TODOs in the PR body.

> Ichange runtime packed function representation to the optimum one.

Just pushed a fix to that (https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2616/commits/3d10c6bd21f3dd5c7eb7c0c8bab7f2393843cfb6). Note that the fat pointer is required if you want to make a `PackedFunc` out of a closure. Otherwise, it's probably sufficient to `from_raw` a C function pointer so to prevent allocation. It shouldn't matter w.r.t. the UI since `Box<T>` is `Deref<T>`

Thanks, @yidawang @zhiics @eqy @yzhliu . Some followup comments would be nice to address as a followup:

- So far the code uses hard-code pattern matching, it is a bit hard to generalize when we add ops
   -  e.g. we need to add support for conv2d_transpose
   -  The attribute registration style works much better in this case: https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/relay/pass/fold_scale_axis.cc#L316
- Avoid the use of dynamic_cast, mainly because it requires RTTI features. In our case, static_cast and our build in generic type checking good for most cases

> Note that the fat pointer is required if you want to make a `PackedFunc` out of a closure.

Right! Frontend `PackedFunc` is not a closure and don't need to be. But for runtime, since you're directly translating `std::function<void (TVMArgs args, TVMRetValue* rv)>;` you can argue that boxing is necessary and so be it.

>  What do you think are the important categories of docs?

I second @FrozenGene's comment. Right now, there's no clear hierarchy in tutorials. We need to consider our users and their level of familiarities. What we would like to give them first and have more for those with more interests. Writing great tutorial is an art and it needs caring which we should strive for when heading to v1.0 release.

What we have is good but not good enough. We need 

0. Very generic overview. `What is TVM?` think how you'd explain it to your parents and not how you write paper!
1. Direct, right on to the point **use cases oriented** broken into compile from onnx, mxnet etc. with nnvm, rpc, autoTVM, quantization etc. _The best would be to work on one task (image classification) end-to-end_
2. Introduction to different **components** (nnvm/relay, tvm, etc.) from **high level** to some useful and interesting **low-level** API details broken into _separate_ tutorials and exercises.
3. **Index all API docs**. Right now, Rust and Golang are missing from index point of view.
4. **Developers** covering backends and all frontends.
@tqchen Now it passes the tests.
@tqchen @were @reminisce Could you kindly do another round of review? Thanks!
could you please help review it when you have a chance? @srkreddy1238

I am a bit against this change. while it seems to improve usability, it harm composability.
To be more specific, we could do x.1 to take all the gradient, and put it into a tuple, so we can build a gradient descent/adam function in relay.
After this change, it is impossible, so how can we move the training loop into relay?
I do agree that improving usability is important, so maybe a better way is to keep the old version (as gradient_raw) alongside the new version.
Thanks for the example. @MarisaKirisame and I will start implementing mutual recursion this week.

Given the current convention, it is still easy to extract the gradient values via outputs[1:]. The main trade-off here is the generality v.s. the convention to favor non-nesting tuples. Non-nesting tuples are easier to optimize in general and work well for old graph runtime, and so I would recommend to keep them when possible.

I agree with Marisa. We have discussed adding a flattening pass for tuples, but I feel we should do that optimization separately from the interface. To me the interface is that we return the forward evaluation AND the gradients as two separate entities.
I am working on adding gradient definition for some level 1/2 operators, see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2633 for details

to be more clear, i think we can have both by having two interface - one general one, for whoever need to write generic code (such as a generic gradient descend), and one where where it is flatten and easier to use.
we cant go from the flatten one to the unflatten one purely inside relay world(we have to goto python)
look like it is fixed. nevermind.

What sort of syntax should there be to indicate mutual recursion? I presume that mutual recursion should always work for globals. However, if, like in your example, we want to enforce that types be annotated for mutually recursive function, we need some way of indicating when functions are intended to be mutually recursive
I feel that it is just about convention and keep nested tuple seems no direct benefit?

> we cant go from the flatten one to the unflatten one purely inside relay world(we have to goto python)

@MarisaKirisame do you mean we cannot express `ret[1:]` in relay?

OK, given the current discussion and suggestions from @MarisaKirisame and @jroesch , let us still keep the original signature, but provide a pass tuple_flatten that flattens the nested tuple into the flattened one

If I understand correctly, enabled is a property of SequentialPass(to whether or not turn an pass on). Basically, you store a list of [(enabled, Pass)] in the sequentialPass

@kazum @ZihengJiang please help to take a look
@tqchen can you review? sorry for the inconvenience.

I think `enabled` maybe more suitable in `PassNode`.
 
Let us imagine we have one tool in the future like `opt` in LLVM. We want to disable one specific pass to check the performance or correctness. So we want to use like this: `opt -disable-pass-name=xx-pass`. Then `SequentialPass` should know the pass is turned off and resolve dependency.  So we set the `enabled` property of `PassNode` be `false`.

However, we could also do it another way. We don't make `enabled` be the property in `PassNode`. But we add many data members like `disable_precompute`, `disable_foldscaleaxis` and so on. If `opt -disable-pass-name`, we make `SequentialPass` `disable_xx` be true. LLVM's `PassManagerBuilder` do it like this way. LLVM's `PassManagerBuilder` construct standard optimization sequential passes like our `SequentialPass`.
Will work together with @icemelon9 on dynamic runtime.

@FrozenGene It looks that we can probably just have a list of disabled passes in `SequentialPass`. For example, if we have a configuration which performs all passes at `opt_level = 3` with some disabled passes `disable-pass=xx, disable=yy`, we probably want to glob all passes at `opt_level = 3` and exclude those in `disabled`.

For other passes, like FunctionPass and ModulePass, we probably only need to glob the required passes and execute. It seems that we don't want to disable any required passes for `FunctionPass` anyway though.

probably due to the fact that we don't want users to uninstall :)

would you mind add one into the tutorial?
@yongwww we welcome contributions :)

Look good to me except that the tensorflow_parser is same for both NNVM and relay.
Consider keeping one copy and use across NNVM and relay. Practice so far was to keep under relay and use it in NNVM.

My goal is to obtain a program fragment like:

```
Function(
  params=[Var("x", type_annotation=TensorType([10, 10], float32))], 
  ret_type=TensorType([10, 10], float32), 
  body=Call(relay.op.get("add"), ...),
 ...)
```

Instead of: 
```
FunctionNode([Var(x, ty=TensorType([10, 10], float32))], TensorType([10, 10], float32), CallNode(Op(add), [Var(x, ty=TensorType([10, 10], float32)), Var(x, ty=TensorType([10, 10], float32))], (nullptr), [TensorType([10, 10], float32), TensorType([10, 10], float32)]), [], (nullptr))
```

Upon further reflection we could just do this in Python, though there are some challenges due to our name representation.

My main goal is that we could obtain  textual representation of the program which can be copy-and pasted back into the interpreter along the idea presented by the `pprint` module (https://docs.python.org/3.7/library/pprint.html). 

My inspiration is that I was writing tests and debugging some transformations and it would be nice to be able to easily manually edit the AST to observe changes instead of having to write a Relay program to do so.

Hello. First thanks for creating TVM, it looks very promising to deploy and speed up networks on different architectures.

(disclaimer: I'm very new to TVM, still working on understanding how it works internally)

I'd like to know if there are plans to speed up transposed convolutions, as right now this makes our networks (U-Net-like) run 2 times slower than in pytorch. Alternatively, is there a way to find a workaround to this 

Is this PR also progress towards that https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/2519 ?
I saw something similar here. I fixed it by forcing the app to link against the `pthread` library, by adding `-Wl,--no-as-needed -lpthread` to the `demo` rule in the Makefile

I think we should also deprecate nnvm fully in 0.6. So far there are still some legacy code in topi depends on nnvm.
Could we also add `Any` dimension support in Relay to the roadmap? I think it's an important feature to have.
Do you think it's worth integrating this code with the text printer? We could e.g. reuse the Doc ADT in #2605.

@merrymercy This PR is intentionally light on new printer functionality and focuses primarily on infrastructure. Once we get the scaffolding down it will be easier to work on the parser and printer. I'm a bit short on time right now so I can't promise that I will be able to add attribute printing, but my hope is that the `Doc` ADT is easy enough to use that people can extend the printer relatively easily.

Thanks for the feedback, @tqchen 

As the MAC counting is an estimation, we only take those computationally-intensive ops into account. Therefore, I don't envision that we will extend it to many ops. We can definitely switch to your suggested attribute registration style if necessary. We will add new ops as needed.

I will send out a quick PR to fix the dynamic cast issue soon.
+1. It would be very useful to have `program == eval(program.repr())`

Is it possible to simply defer the type inference of a module and only do inference after we put in all the functions? This seems will also affect our future passes who need type information over transformed functions in a module.
Thanks. Currently, I cannot use the text format because I cannot write attributes in the text format. Although I can hack it to support some constants.

'data' in tvm can be composed by the 'boxes' and 'score' in tf/pt.
valid_counts is to support different ways to generate valid number of boxes, as we have discussed. We don't need score_threshold in this api then.
The extra argument 'return_indices' is to decide whether to return box indices. I put it right after the input tensor since it is mandatory.
Other additional arguments make tvm implementation the superset of tf/pt implementation. When converting tf/pt nms, we need to set 
```
    force_suppress=True,
    topk=-1,
    id_index=0,
    invalid_to_bottom=False
```
